cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where was the original planet of the apes filmed at
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine where the original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed, I need to recall the details about the production of the film. The original "Planet of the Apes" movie was released in 1968 and is a science fiction film based on the novel by Pierre Boulle. The film was produced by 20th Century Fox. 

I remember that many scenes in the movie were shot in California, particularly in locations that could represent a post-apocalyptic Earth. One of the most notable filming locations was the Los Angeles area, including the famous Malibu Creek State Park, which provided the backdrop for many of the outdoor scenes.

Answer:
The original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed primarily in California, with notable locations including Malibu Creek State Park.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where was the original planet of the apes filmed at
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['A brief scene from Planet of the apes movie remake was shot on the barren landscape of shanmaghery. This is not widely known as the film makers did not want the media attention surrounding the likes of Mark Wahlberg when they arrived on set and it was only divulged by director Tim Burton years after the movie was released\n', 'Burton wanted to begin filming in October 2000, but it was pushed back to November 6, 2000 and ended in April 2001. Filming for "Planet of the Apes" began at Lake Powell, where parts of the original film were shot. Due to a local drought, production crews had to pump in extra water. The film was mostly shot at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, while other filming locations included lava plains in Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles at Ridgecrest. To preserve secrecy, the shooting script did not include the ending. Stan Winston was the original makeup designer but left because of creative differences. Fox considered using computer-generated imagery to create the apes, but Burton insisted on using prosthetic makeup designed by Rick Baker. Baker was previously involved with Adam Rifkin\'s unproduced remake. Burton commented, "I have a relationship with both of them [Winston and Baker], so that decision was hard," he says. "Stan worked on "Edward Scissorhands" and Baker did Martin Landau\'s makeup [as Béla Lugosi in "Ed Wood"]".\n', '"Planet of the Apes" commenced filming on May 21, 1967 and ended August 10, 1967. The first scenes were shot on locations near Page, Arizona. Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River stood in for the Forbidden Zone, through which Taylor, Zira, Cornelius, and Harrison\'s Nova fled after escaping from Ape City. Harrison, who had the company of her oldest sister Kay on location with her, found working in the desert "beautiful", and marveled "how they move an entire production, like a little mini-town, and set up."\n', '"The Ape" was filmed in the city of Newhall, Santa Clarita, California.\n', 'According to "The Guardian", the video was shot at The Imaginarium, where the reboot series of "Planet of the Apes" and parts of "" and "" were filmed.\n', '"Ape" made its world premiere at the 2012 Locarno Film Festival, where it won Best New Director and Best First Feature Special Mention at the festival. It went on to make its North American premiere at the Vancouver International Film Festival, and US premiere at AFI Fest in Hollywood. The film received a theatrical release through Factory 25.\n', 'Important scenes in the "Planet of the Apes" series were filmed at Point Dume\'s Westward Beach.\n', 'Given Weta had plenty of experience creating animated apes in "King Kong" and "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and its sequels "Dawn" and "War", it helped the studio create George "in a much shorter time than it may have 10 years ago," according to Winquist. Motion capture coach Terry Notary even took a break from "", which was also filmed in Atlanta, to help Jason Liles in his performance as George. On the other hand, the lack of motion capture for Ralph and Lizzie let the animators go loose with how these monsters were portrayed, such as "a wolf that has porcupine spines and wings".\n', 'To convince the Fox Studio that a "Planet of the Apes" film could be made, the producers shot a brief test scene from a Rod Serling draft of the script, using early versions of the ape makeup, on March 8, 1966. Charlton Heston appeared as an early version of Taylor (named Thomas, as he was in the Serling-penned drafts), Edward G. Robinson appeared as Zaius, while two then-unknown Fox contract actors, James Brolin and Linda Harrison, played Cornelius and Zira. This test footage is included on several DVD releases of the film, as well as the documentary "Behind the Planet of the Apes". Linda Harrison, at the time the girlfriend of studio chief Richard D. Zanuck, went on to play Nova in the 1968 film and its first sequel, and had a cameo in Tim Burton\'s "Planet of the Apes" more than 30 years later, which was also produced by Zanuck. Although Harrison often opined that the producers had always had her in mind for the role of Nova, they had, in fact, considered first Ursula Andress, then Raquel Welch, and Angelique Pettyjohn. When these three women proved unavailable or uninterested, Zanuck gave the part to Harrison. Dr. Zaius was originally to have been played by Robinson, but he backed out due to the heavy makeup and long sessions required to apply it. Robinson later made his final film, "Soylent Green" (1973), opposite his one-time "Ten Commandments" (1956) co-star Heston.\n', 'BULLET::::- Mt. Tamalpais State Park is the home location of the apes in "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes." A "Mt. Tamalpais State Park" sign can be seen as the apes return home from their hunting expedition early in the movie.\n']

   **Role**: This information establishes the historical context and primary filming locations for the original film, which is crucial for answering the question about where it was filmed.

   **Role**: This detail highlights the logistical challenges faced during production, providing insight into the complexities of filming in natural locations.

3. **Comparison with Remakes**:
   - The passages reference Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes," which was filmed at various locations, including Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, and other sites like Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles.

   **Role**: Understanding the differences in filming locations between the original and the remake can help contextualize the evolution of the franchise and the filmmakers' choices over time.

4. **Makeup and Special Effects**:

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine where the original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed, I need to recall the details about the production of the film. The original "Planet of the Apes" movie was released in 1968 and is a science fiction film based on the novel by Pierre Boulle. The film was produced by 20th Century Fox.

1. **Filming Timeline and Locations**: 
   - The film commenced filming on May 21, 1967, and concluded on August 10, 1967. The first scenes were shot near Page, Arizona, specifically at Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River, which represented the Forbidden Zone in the film. This information is crucial as it establishes the primary filming locations.

2. **California Locations**: 
   - Many outdoor scenes were filmed in California, particularly at Malibu Creek State Park, which provided a suitable backdrop for the post-apocalyptic setting. This aligns with the model's initial recall of filming in California.

3. **Production Challenges**: 
   - The production faced challenges such as a local drought at Lake Powell, where additional water had to be pumped in for filming. This detail highlights the logistical complexities involved in shooting in natural locations.

4. **Comparison with Remakes**: 
   - Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes" was filmed at various locations, including Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, and other sites like Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles. Understanding these differences helps contextualize the evolution of the franchise.

5. **Makeup and Special Effects**: 
   - The original film utilized prosthetic makeup designed by Rick Baker, which was significant for its time. This contrasts with the later use of computer-generated imagery in remakes, emphasizing the practical effects that contributed to the film's iconic status.

6. **Cultural Impact and Legacy**: 
   - The film's early development included test footage shot in 1966 with notable actors like Charlton Heston and Edward G. Robinson. This context enriches the understanding of the film's legacy and the contributions of its cast.

7. **Additional Filming Locations**: 
   - Other locations mentioned, such as Point Dume's Westward Beach and Mt. Tamalpais State Park, indicate the broader use of diverse landscapes in the "Planet of the Apes" franchise.

By synthesizing this information, I can provide a more comprehensive answer regarding the filming locations of the original "Planet of the Apes."

### Answer:
The original "Planet of the Apes" was primarily filmed in Arizona, with significant scenes shot at Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River, which represented the Forbidden Zone. Additional filming took place in California, notably at Malibu Creek State Park, which provided the backdrop for many outdoor scenes. The filming occurred between May 21, 1967, and August 10, 1967.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the Filming Locations of "Planet of the Apes"**

**Expert 1: Film Historian**
The original "Planet of the Apes," released in 1968, was primarily filmed in locations near Page, Arizona. Notably, Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River served as the backdrop for the Forbidden Zone. This location choice was significant because it provided a stark, otherworldly landscape that contributed to the film's dystopian atmosphere. The use of natural landscapes in Arizona was a strategic decision to enhance the film's visual storytelling.

**Expert 2: Cinematic Techniques Specialist**
While I agree with the Film Historian about the Arizona locations, I would like to emphasize the importance of the production techniques used during filming. The filmmakers created a mini-town setup to facilitate the logistics of shooting in remote areas. This approach not only allowed for efficient production but also contributed to the immersive experience of the film. The combination of practical effects and location shooting was crucial in establishing the film's iconic imagery.

**Expert 3: Modern Filmmaking Analyst**
It's interesting to note that while the original film utilized natural landscapes, the 2001 remake directed by Tim Burton took a different approach. Most of the filming occurred at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, with additional scenes shot in Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles. This shift reflects a broader trend in modern filmmaking where studios often rely on controlled environments for shooting, allowing for more elaborate set designs and special effects.

**Expert 4: Location Scout**
From a location scouting perspective, the choice of Arizona for the original film was not just about aesthetics; it was also about accessibility and the unique geological features that could stand in for an alien world. The filmmakers had to consider practicalities such as weather and terrain, which is why locations like Lake Powell were chosen for their dramatic landscapes. 

**Expert 5: Cultural Context Expert**
I would like to add that the filming locations also played a role in the cultural context of the film. The desolate landscapes of Arizona echoed the themes of isolation and the fall of civilization, which were central to the narrative. The choice of these locations was not merely aesthetic but deeply intertwined with the film's commentary on humanity and its future.

**Synthesis of Insights**
In summary, the original "Planet of the Apes" was primarily filmed near Page, Arizona, with Horseshoe Bend serving as a key location for the Forbidden Zone. The production utilized practical effects and natural landscapes to create an immersive experience that resonated with the film's themes. In contrast, the 2001 remake shifted towards studio-based filming, reflecting changes in filmmaking techniques and the industry's reliance on controlled environments. 

The discussion highlights the importance of location in film not only for visual impact but also for thematic depth. The differing perspectives on filming techniques and cultural implications enrich our understanding of how location choices influence narrative and audience perception. This collaborative dialogue underscores the multifaceted nature of filmmaking, where practical, aesthetic, and thematic considerations converge to create a compelling cinematic experience.

It went on to make its North American premiere at the Vancouver International Film Festival, and US premiere at AFI Fest in Hollywood. The film received a theatrical release through Factory 25.
', 'Important scenes in the "Planet of the Apes" series were filmed at Point Dume's Westward Beach.
', 'Given Weta had plenty of experience creating animated apes in "King Kong" and "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and its sequels "Dawn" and "War", it helped the studio create George "in a much shorter time than it may have 10 years ago," according to Winquist. Motion capture coach Terry Notary even took a break from "", which was also filmed in Atlanta, to help Jason Liles in his performance as George. On the other hand, the lack of motion capture for Ralph and Lizzie let the animators go loose with how these monsters were portrayed, such as "a wolf that has porcupine spines and wings".
', 'To convince the Fox Studio that a "Planet of the Apes" film could be made, the producers shot a brief test scene from a Rod Serling draft of the script, using early versions of the ape makeup, on March 8, 1966. Charlton Heston appeared as an early version of Taylor (named Thomas, as he was in the Serling-penned drafts), Edward G. Robinson appeared as Zaius, while two then-unknown Fox contract actors, James Brolin and Linda Harrison, played Cornelius and Zira. This test footage is included on several DVD releases of the film, as well as the documentary "Behind the Planet of the Apes". Linda Harrison, at the time the girlfriend of studio chief Richard D. Zanuck, went on to play Nova in the 1968 film and its first sequel, and had a cameo in Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" more than 30 years later, which was also produced by Zanuck. Although Harrison often opined that the producers had always had her in mind for the role of Nova, they had, in fact, considered first Ursula Andress, then Raquel Welch, and Angelique Pettyjohn. When these three women proved unavailable or uninterested, Zanuck gave the part to Harrison. Dr. Zaius was originally to have been played by Robinson, but he backed out due to the heavy makeup and long sessions required to apply it. Robinson later made his final film, "Soylent Green" (1973), opposite his one-time "Ten Commandments" (1956) co-star Heston.
', 'BULLET::::- Mt. Tamalpais State Park is the home location of the apes in "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes." A "Mt. Tamalpais State Park" sign can be seen as the apes return home from their hunting expedition early in the movie.
']

Task Description:

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the filming locations of the original "Planet of the Apes" movie. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Original Filming Dates and Locations**:
   - "Planet of the Apes" commenced filming on May 21, 1967, and ended on August 10, 1967.
   - The first scenes were shot near Page, Arizona, specifically at Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River, which served as the Forbidden Zone.

2. **Additional Filming Locations**:
   - Important scenes were also filmed at Point Dume's Westward Beach.
   - The film's production involved a mini-town setup in the desert, indicating a significant logistical operation.

3. **Context of Filming**:
   - The production faced challenges, such as moving an entire crew and equipment to remote locations, which reflects the complexity of film production logistics.
   - The use of specific landscapes (like the Colorado River) to represent fictional settings demonstrates the importance of location in storytelling and world-building.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**:
   - The model can learn to associate specific filming locations with the narrative elements they represent (e.g., how the natural landscape contributes to the film's themes of isolation and exploration).
   - Recognizing that logistical challenges (like transporting a crew) can affect production timelines and the final output of a film can enhance the model's ability to infer relationships between actions and outcomes.

2. **Contextual Inference**:
   - The model can improve its ability to infer the significance of location choices in filmmaking, understanding that certain settings can evoke specific emotions or themes in a narrative.
   - By analyzing how different locations were used to represent fictional worlds, the model can better grasp the implications of setting in storytelling.

3. **Complexity of Production**:
   - The details about the production process (e.g., the mini-town setup) can help the model understand the multifaceted nature of film production, including the interplay between creative decisions and logistical realities.
   - This understanding can lead to more nuanced reasoning about how various factors (like location, crew size, and equipment) influence the final product.

4. **Interconnectedness of Elements**:
   - The model can learn to see the interconnectedness of various elements in filmmaking (e.g., location, narrative, production logistics) and how they collectively contribute to the storytelling process.
   - This holistic view can enhance the model's ability to make logical inferences about how changes in one aspect (like location) can impact others (like narrative effectiveness).

In summary, the extracted information provides a foundation for enhancing the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by illustrating the relationships between filming locations, production logistics, and narrative elements in filmmaking. This understanding can lead to more sophisticated reasoning about cause-and-effect scenarios in various contexts.

question:
where was the original planet of the apes filmed at
answer:
Reasoning process: 
To determine where the original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed, I need to recall the details about the production of the film. The original "Planet of the Apes" movie was released in 1968 and is a science fiction film based on the novel by Pierre Boulle. The film was produced by 20th Century Fox. 

I remember that many scenes in the movie were shot in California, particularly in locations that could represent a post-apocalyptic Earth. One of the most notable filming locations was the Los Angeles area, including the famous Malibu Creek State Park, which provided the backdrop for many of the outdoor scenes.

Answer:
The original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed primarily in California, with notable locations including Malibu Creek State Park.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine where the original "Planet of the Apes" was filmed, I will analyze the details surrounding the production of the film, which was released in 1968 and is based on Pierre Boulle's novel. The film was produced by 20th Century Fox, and its production involved various logistical considerations.

1. **Filming Timeline**: The original "Planet of the Apes" commenced filming on May 21, 1967, and concluded on August 10, 1967. This timeframe is crucial for contextualizing the filming locations within the era's production practices.

2. **Primary Filming Locations**:
   - The first scenes were shot near Page, Arizona, specifically at Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River, which served as the Forbidden Zone in the film. This location is significant as it visually represents the desolate and alien landscape that is central to the film's narrative.
   - Additional important scenes were filmed at Point Dume's Westward Beach in California, which provided a contrasting coastal setting that contributed to the film's diverse visual palette.

3. **Production Logistics**: The production involved setting up a mini-town in the desert, indicating the complexity of moving an entire crew and equipment to remote locations. This logistical challenge reflects the broader realities of film production, where location choices can significantly impact the feasibility and execution of a project.

4. **Narrative and Thematic Implications**: The choice of specific landscapes, such as the Colorado River and coastal areas, not only serves practical purposes but also enhances the film's themes of isolation, exploration, and the consequences of human actions on the environment. Understanding these connections allows for a deeper appreciation of how location influences storytelling.

5. **Causal Relationships**: Recognizing that logistical challenges (like transporting a crew) can affect production timelines and the final output of a film enhances the model's ability to infer relationships between actions and outcomes. For example, the choice of Arizona and California locations was likely influenced by their ability to visually represent the film's themes while also being logistically feasible for the production team.

By synthesizing these points, I can enhance my reasoning about the significance of the filming locations in relation to the film's narrative and production challenges.

### Answer:
The original "Planet of the Apes" was primarily filmed in Arizona and California. Key locations included Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River, which represented the Forbidden Zone, and Point Dume's Westward Beach in California. The production faced logistical challenges in moving crews and equipment to these remote sites, which contributed to the film's unique visual storytelling and thematic depth.

Filming for "Planet of the Apes" began at Lake Powell, where parts of the original film were shot. Due to a local drought, production crews had to pump in extra water. The film was mostly shot at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, while other filming locations included lava plains in Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles at Ridgecrest. To preserve secrecy, the shooting script did not include the ending. Stan Winston was the original makeup designer but left because of creative differences. Fox considered using computer-generated imagery to create the apes, but Burton insisted on using prosthetic makeup designed by Rick Baker. Baker was previously involved with Adam Rifkin\'s unproduced remake. Burton commented, "I have a relationship with both of them [Winston and Baker], so that decision was hard," he says. "Stan worked on "Edward Scissorhands" and Baker did Martin Landau\'s makeup [as Béla Lugosi in "Ed Wood"]".\n', '"Planet of the Apes" commenced filming on May 21, 1967 and ended August 10, 1967. The first scenes were shot on locations near Page, Arizona. Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River stood in for the Forbidden Zone, through which Taylor, Zira, Cornelius, and Harrison\'s Nova fled after escaping from Ape City. Harrison, who had the company of her oldest sister Kay on location with her, found working in the desert "beautiful", and marveled "how they move an entire production, like a little mini-town, and set up."\n', '"The Ape" was filmed in the city of Newhall, Santa Clarita, California.\n', 'According to "The Guardian", the video was shot at The Imaginarium, where the reboot series of "Planet of the Apes" and parts of "" and "" were filmed.\n', '"Ape" made its world premiere at the 2012 Locarno Film Festival, where it won Best New Director and Best First Feature Special Mention at the festival. It went on to make its North American premiere at the Vancouver International Film Festival, and US premiere at AFI Fest in Hollywood. The film received a theatrical release through Factory 25.\n', 'Important scenes in the "Planet of the Apes" series were filmed at Point Dume\'s Westward Beach.\n', 'Given Weta had plenty of experience creating animated apes in "King Kong" and "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and its sequels "Dawn" and "War", it helped the studio create George "in a much shorter time than it may have 10 years ago," according to Winquist. Motion capture coach Terry Notary even took a break from "", which was also filmed in Atlanta, to help Jason Liles in his performance as George. On the other hand, the lack of motion capture for Ralph and Lizzie let the animators go loose with how these monsters were portrayed, such as "a wolf that has porcupine spines and wings".\n', 'To convince the Fox Studio that a "Planet of the Apes" film could be made, the producers shot a brief test scene from a Rod Serling draft of the script, using early versions of the ape makeup, on March 8, 1966. Charlton Heston appeared as an early version of Taylor (named Thomas, as he was in the Serling-penned drafts), Edward G. Robinson appeared as Zaius, while two then-unknown Fox contract actors, James Brolin and Linda Harrison, played Cornelius and Zira. This test footage is included on several DVD releases of the film, as well as the documentary "Behind the Planet of the Apes". Linda Harrison, at the time the girlfriend of studio chief Richard D. Zanuck, went on to play Nova in the 1968 film and its first sequel, and had a cameo in Tim Burton\'s "Planet of the Apes" more than 30 years later, which was also produced by Zanuck. Although Harrison often opined that the producers had always had her in mind for the role of Nova, they had, in fact, considered first Ursula Andress, then Raquel Welch, and Angelique Pettyjohn. When these three women proved unavailable or uninterested, Zanuck gave the part to Harrison. Dr. Zaius was originally to have been played by Robinson, but he backed out due to the heavy makeup and long sessions required to apply it. Robinson later made his final film, "Soylent Green" (1973), opposite his one-time "Ten Commandments" (1956) co-star Heston.\n', 'BULLET::::- Mt. Tamalpais State Park is the home location of the apes in "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes." A "Mt. Tamalpais State Park" sign can be seen as the apes return home from their hunting expedition early in the movie.\n']

question_info.question: where was the original planet of the apes filmed at
passages:
A brief scene from Planet of the apes movie remake was shot on the barren landscape of shanmaghery. This is not widely known as the film makers did not want the media attention surrounding the likes of Mark Wahlberg when they arrived on set and it was only divulged by director Tim Burton years after the movie was released
Burton wanted to begin filming in October 2000, but it was pushed back to November 6, 2000 and ended in April 2001. Filming for "Planet of the Apes" began at Lake Powell, where parts of the original film were shot. Due to a local drought, production crews had to pump in extra water. The film was mostly shot at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, while other filming locations included lava plains in Hawaii and Trona Pinnacles at Ridgecrest. To preserve secrecy, the shooting script did not include the ending. Stan Winston was the original makeup designer but left because of creative differences. Fox considered using computer-generated imagery to create the apes, but Burton insisted on using prosthetic makeup designed by Rick Baker. Baker was previously involved with Adam Rifkin's unproduced remake. Burton commented, "I have a relationship with both of them [Winston and Baker], so that decision was hard," he says. "Stan worked on "Edward Scissorhands" and Baker did Martin Landau's makeup [as Béla Lugosi in "Ed Wood"]".
"Planet of the Apes" commenced filming on May 21, 1967 and ended August 10, 1967. The first scenes were shot on locations near Page, Arizona. Horseshoe Bend on the Colorado River stood in for the Forbidden Zone, through which Taylor, Zira, Cornelius, and Harrison's Nova fled after escaping from Ape City. Harrison, who had the company of her oldest sister Kay on location with her, found working in the desert "beautiful", and marveled "how they move an entire production, like a little mini-town, and set up."
"The Ape" was filmed in the city of Newhall, Santa Clarita, California.
According to "The Guardian", the video was shot at The Imaginarium, where the reboot series of "Planet of the Apes" and parts of "" and "" were filmed.
"Ape" made its world premiere at the 2012 Locarno Film Festival, where it won Best New Director and Best First Feature Special Mention at the festival. It went on to make its North American premiere at the Vancouver International Film Festival, and US premiere at AFI Fest in Hollywood. The film received a theatrical release through Factory 25.
Important scenes in the "Planet of the Apes" series were filmed at Point Dume's Westward Beach.
Given Weta had plenty of experience creating animated apes in "King Kong" and "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and its sequels "Dawn" and "War", it helped the studio create George "in a much shorter time than it may have 10 years ago," according to Winquist. Motion capture coach Terry Notary even took a break from "", which was also filmed in Atlanta, to help Jason Liles in his performance as George. On the other hand, the lack of motion capture for Ralph and Lizzie let the animators go loose with how these monsters were portrayed, such as "a wolf that has porcupine spines and wings".
To convince the Fox Studio that a "Planet of the Apes" film could be made, the producers shot a brief test scene from a Rod Serling draft of the script, using early versions of the ape makeup, on March 8, 1966. Charlton Heston appeared as an early version of Taylor (named Thomas, as he was in the Serling-penned drafts), Edward G. Robinson appeared as Zaius, while two then-unknown Fox contract actors, James Brolin and Linda Harrison, played Cornelius and Zira. This test footage is included on several DVD releases of the film, as well as the documentary "Behind the Planet of the Apes". Linda Harrison, at the time the girlfriend of studio chief Richard D. Zanuck, went on to play Nova in the 1968 film and its first sequel, and had a cameo in Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" more than 30 years later, which was also produced by Zanuck. Although Harrison often opined that the producers had always had her in mind for the role of Nova, they had, in fact, considered first Ursula Andress, then Raquel Welch, and Angelique Pettyjohn. When these three women proved unavailable or uninterested, Zanuck gave the part to Harrison. Dr. Zaius was originally to have been played by Robinson, but he backed out due to the heavy makeup and long sessions required to apply it. Robinson later made his final film, "Soylent Green" (1973), opposite his one-time "Ten Commandments" (1956) co-star Heston.
BULLET::::- Mt. Tamalpais State Park is the home location of the apes in "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes." A "Mt. Tamalpais State Park" sign can be seen as the apes return home from their hunting expedition early in the movie.
__answers__: on the Fox Ranch in Malibu Creek State Park , northwest of Los Angeles
in a secluded cove on the far eastern end of Westward Beach , between Zuma Beach and Point Dume in Malibu
on a stretch of California seacoast between Malibu and Oxnard
Lake Powell , Glen Canyon National Recreation Area
